expanded_description: This section introduces science as a systematic and evidence-based way of understanding the natural world, with a focus on observation, experimentation, and logical reasoning used in physics.

core_concept.principle: Science is a systematic process used to study natural phenomena through observation, experimentation, and evidence-based reasoning.
core_concept.explanation: In physics, science helps us understand how and why natural events occur by forming explanations that can be tested, measured, and verified using experiments and observations.

sections.introduction: Science is a disciplined way of learning about the universe. It focuses on understanding natural phenomena by observing patterns, asking questions, and testing ideas using evidence.

key_concept.definition: Science is the systematic study of the natural world through observation, experimentation, and logical reasoning.
key_concept.context: Physics uses science to explain motion, forces, energy, light, electricity, and other natural phenomena.

principles.statement: Scientific knowledge is based on observable and measurable evidence.
principles.application: Physicists rely on measurements, experiments, and data rather than opinions or beliefs.
principles.example: The speed of a moving object is calculated using measured distance and time.

sections.introduction: Scientific knowledge has specific features that distinguish it from guesses, opinions, or beliefs.

classifications.behavior: Relies on data collected using instruments and experiments.

examples.explanation: A thermometer provides numerical data that can be recorded and compared.

classifications.behavior: Different scientists performing the same experiment should obtain similar results.

examples.explanation: Objects dropped from the same height fall with the same acceleration regardless of who performs the experiment.

classifications.value: Open to revision with new evidence
classifications.behavior: Scientific explanations may change when new experimental data is discovered.

examples.explanation: Models of the atom have changed as experimental techniques improved.

sections.introduction: Physics is a branch of science that studies matter, energy, motion, and forces, and how they interact.

components.definition: Physics applies scientific methods to understand the fundamental laws governing natural phenomena.
components.interpretation: It explains everyday events such as motion of vehicles, flow of electricity, and propagation of sound.

categories.description: Focuses on conducting experiments and making measurements to test ideas.

examples.explanation: Measuring how different surfaces affect the motion of an object.

categories.description: Uses mathematical models and logical reasoning to explain observations.

examples.explanation: Predicting the position and velocity of objects over time.

sections.introduction: Observation and experimentation form the foundation of scientific inquiry in physics.

process_flow.description: Carefully noticing and recording natural events or phenomena.
process_flow.result: Identification of patterns or problems to investigate.

process_flow.description: Designing controlled tests to study cause-and-effect relationships.
process_flow.mechanism: Changing one variable while keeping others constant.

process_flow.description: Interpreting results to form explanations or laws.

summary: Science is a systematic, evidence-based approach to understanding the natural world. In physics, it involves observing phenomena, performing experiments, collecting data, and forming explanations that can be tested and refined over time.
